propositions.text: The story takes place in the summer of 1947.
An international passenger ship is sailing towards Qingdao in the darkness.
The sea is calm at night.
Most passengers are resting.
In a special suite on the top of the ship, a person is preparing clothes.
This person is wearing a black tight-fitting night suit and a black headscarf, resembling a ninja.
The person skillfully exits through a ventilation window.
In the adjacent suite, three foreigners with blue eyes and yellow hair are present.
One is a middle-aged man, a colonel, reading a book and smoking a cigar.
The other two are young men, his attendants.
They are speaking German, suggesting they are from Germany.
The colonel instructs one of the attendants to take the book and wake him before arrival at Qingdao port.
The attendant carefully wraps the book and places it in a leather suitcase.
The person in the black suit observes all their actions from behind the ventilation window.
After the room quiets down, the person in black drops silently from the ventilation window.
The person lands gracefully and quickly incapacitates the guard with a swift knife attack.
The person retrieves the book from the suitcase and hides it.
One of the young attendants returns and confronts the intruder.
A fight ensues between the intruder and the two Germans.
The intruder escapes into the corridor and is pursued by other Germans.
The story transitions to the first chapter, titled 'Maritime Encounter'.
Two years have passed since the victory in the World Anti-Fascist War.
China is still recovering from war and facing civil conflict.
Dongfang Kun, a young man who studied abroad, returns to China to serve his country.
He is on a ship heading to Qingdao.
Dongfang Kun is excited to return to his homeland for the first time.
His father, Dongfang Congjian, is a well-known patriotic overseas Chinese businessman in Southeast Asia.
Dongfang Kun was sent to study in the US by his father before the Japanese occupation of Singapore.
He joined the fight against fascism during the Pacific War and was injured in the Battle of Okinawa.
The special suites on the ship are comparable to hotel suites.
Dongfang Kun is too excited to sleep, pacing and looking out the window.
He goes to the deck to see if he can spot land or the lighthouse at the entrance of Jiaozhou Bay.
Jiaozhou Bay was forcibly leased by Germany in 1898, occupied by Japan in 1914, and returned to China in 1922.
Dongfang Kun feels the sea breeze and calms his mind.
Suddenly, sounds of a fierce fight are heard from the stern of the ship.
Curiosity leads Dongfang Kun to investigate.
On the rear deck, he sees three burly men attacking a small, black-clad figure, with another man observing.
The attackers are foreigners.
The observing man, identified as a colonel, urges his men in German to capture the intruder and retrieve stolen goods.
Dongfang Kun realizes they are Germans and suspects they might be Nazi remnants.
He notices the black-clad figure appears to be a woman.
The woman tries to escape towards Dongfang Kun's side but is overwhelmed.
She is kicked and falls to the deck in front of Dongfang Kun.
A soft cry confirms she is a woman.
Enraged by three men attacking a woman, Dongfang Kun intervenes.
He incapacitates one of the attackers with a kick and then engages the others in a fight.
Dongfang Kun, trained in Chinese martial arts and military combat, easily fends off their attacks.
One of the Germans draws a dagger, but Dongfang Kun disarms and subdues him.
The colonel draws a pistol, but Dongfang Kun uses one of the subdued Germans as a shield and throws the dagger, hitting the colonel's wrist.
Dongfang Kun then seizes the pistol and aims it at the remaining Germans.
He recognizes the Walther PPK pistol as belonging to high-ranking German officers or secret agents, further confirming their identity.
The Germans retreat after realizing they are outmatched.
Dongfang Kun turns the black-clad figure over and her headscarf falls off, revealing a beautiful young woman.
He carries the unconscious woman to his cabin and gives her water.
He finds a rectangular object wrapped in silk on the carpet, which he believes is the stolen item.
The object is a yellowed, hard-covered notebook, likely a maritime log.
The cover has an anchor symbol and the text is in German.
The log details the sinking of the German ironclad warship 'Prince Wilhelm' from Qingdao in 1914, before WWI.
Dongfang Kun, interested in history and exploration, becomes engrossed in the log.
A ship's horn signals their imminent arrival at Qingdao port.
He realizes the woman has woken up and is smiling at him.
He returns the logbook to the woman, who introduces herself as Yan Li and thanks him for saving her.
They learn that Dongfang Kun is returning from the US, and Yan Li is also going to Qingdao.
Yan Li quickly leaves after thanking Dongfang Kun.
Dongfang Kun doesn't realize he has already attracted trouble.
Meanwhile, the Germans in another cabin are plotting their next move.
The injured German vows revenge on Dongfang Kun.
The colonel plans to retrieve the logbook and eliminate both Dongfang Kun and Yan Li, as anyone who knows about the treasure must die.
They decide to wait until they reach Qingdao port and alert their contacts there.
Dongfang Kun packs his luggage, putting the Walther PPK pistol into his suitcase.
The ship docks at Qingdao port.
Dongfang Kun is met by Ah Qiang, a loyal family servant.
They hire rickshaws to go to the train station, and Dongfang Kun is impressed by Qingdao's European architecture.
At the train station, Ah Qiang mentions that their hometown, Fangzi town, also has similar European architecture, which was built by the Germans.
Ah Qiang also recalls that during renovations at their home, two record books were found in a hidden compartment, one with an anchor symbol on the cover.
Dongfang Kun's interest is piqued, as it sounds like the maritime logbook he saw on the ship.
They head to the train station to buy tickets to Jinan.
Two men in a BMW follow them from the port to the train station.
Fangzi town was established due to coal mining and the railway, and was under German and then Japanese colonial rule.
During their rule, Fangzi became a significant base for German and Japanese expansion and economic plunder.
The train arrives at Fangzi station.
Dongfang Kun's parents are waiting at the station, and they have an emotional reunion.
Dongfang Kun notices that the Fangzi station is also a typical German-style building.
His father, Dongfang Congjian, is a successful industrialist in Fangzi.
They arrive at their home, the former German commander's residence, a beautiful German-style villa.
Dongfang Kun asks his father about the two notebooks found during renovations.
His father promises to show them later, as his mother wants him to bathe and have a family dinner.
Dongfang Congjian respects his son's choice to study architecture, despite his initial disappointment.
The next day, Dongfang Kun receives the two notebooks, feeling a premonition of a hidden secret.
He recognizes one of the notebooks as being identical to the maritime logbook from the ship.
He retreats to his study to research the notebooks, discovering an astonishing secret.
The notebooks detail the sinking of the German ironclad cruiser 'Prince Wilhelm' before World War I.
Japanese militarism coveted the Shandong Peninsula, and the German garrison felt pressure from the Japanese navy.
The German acting governor of Jiaozhou, Admiral Dekerner, ordered the treasures plundered from China to be transported back to Germany.
The 'Prince Wilhelm' was one of several warships used to smuggle these treasures.

The second notebook contains detailed information about the cargo of the 'Prince Wilhelm', including vast amounts of gold and silver, as well as precious cultural relics and national treasures stolen from China.
One particular item was highly valued by the Germans: the 'Arrow of Destiny', believed to have been manufactured by Genghis Khan.
Legend says the Mongol Empire's conquests were aided by the mystical power of the 'Arrow of Destiny'.
Genghis Khan gathered skilled artisans and advanced technology to create superior weapons, including these mystical arrows.
The arrows were said to possess divine power, granting dominion over the world to their wielder.
Genghis Khan distributed four of these arrows to his sons and kept one for himself, making them symbols of power and strength.
The Mongol Empire at its peak was vast, encompassing much of Asia and parts of Europe.
Kublai Khan, holding the last 'Arrow of Destiny', was seen as having suzerain rights over the other Khanates.
Millennia later, the 'Arrow of Destiny' fell into the hands of the invading German army, who sought to establish a German empire akin to the Mongol Empire.
The arrow was placed in a special container crafted by Governor Dekerner and rarely seen by many.
In the early summer of 1914, the 'Prince Wilhelm' secretly departed from Qingdao port, carrying the treasure and the 'Arrow of Destiny'.
The 'Prince Wilhelm' was one of Germany's most advanced warships at the time.
Fearing interception by Japanese ships, the 'Prince Wilhelm' sailed closer to the Chinese mainland.
The crew discovered plumes of smoke rising from the seabed, despite no known reefs or islands in the area.
The 'Prince Wilhelm' ran aground on a reef, sustaining severe damage to its hull and flooding its compartments.
Fearing discovery by Japanese warships, the crew attempted repairs without sending a distress signal.
A volcanic island then mysteriously emerged from the seabed near the stranded warship.
The ship was unable to move due to its position on a steep underwater mountain range and severe hull damage.
Captain Henry Rosenthal ordered the treasures hidden in a cave on the newly formed island, with the entrance sealed.
Suddenly, a storm erupted, and the island began to disappear back into the sea, followed by the sinking of the 'Prince Wilhelm'.
Only three crew members survived by clinging to a life raft that was subsequently sunk by the waves.
The maritime logbook that Dongfang Kun found belonged to these three survivors.
Shortly after, World War I began, and Japan declared war on Germany.

main_topics: Introduction and initial events on the ship
Dongfang Kun's return and return to China
The fight on the ship and the discovery of the logbook
Family reunion and discovery of hidden documents
The historical secret of the 'Arrow of Destiny' and the sinking of the 'Prince Wilhelm'
hierarchy.structure: The document begins with an intriguing prologue detailing a mysterious event on a ship. It then transitions to introduce the protagonist, Dongfang Kun, and his return to China, weaving in historical context and his personal background. The narrative follows Dongfang Kun's journey, leading to further action and the uncovering of a significant historical secret related to a lost treasure and a sunken warship. The structure moves from immediate plot to character introduction, then to historical exposition and a climactic revelation.
